description: From exculpate +‎ -ory (suffix forming adjectives with the sense ‘of or pertaining to, serving for’). Exculpate is derived from Medieval Latin exculpātus and Latin exculptus, the perfect passive participle of exculpō, from ex- (prefix meaning ‘out, away’) + culpa (“defect, fault; crime”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kʷelp-).

adjectives.description: exculpatory (comparative more exculpatory, superlative most exculpatory)

entries.meaning: Tending to excuse or clear of wrongdoing.
examples: Antonyms: criminative, criminatory, incriminating, incriminatory, inculpatory, nonexculpatory
